1.00.text: G'day viewers! My name’s Graeme Stevenson

3.49.text: and I'd like to invite you to come on a journey

5.31.text:
of creativity and learning and adventure
through the series Colour In Your Life.

9.79.text:
There's an artist in every family
throughout  the world.

12.56.text:
Lots of times there's an artist
deep down inside all of us as well.

15.95.text: So grab your kids, your brothers, your sisters,

19.45.text: your aunties, uncles, and mums and dads,

21.98.text:
and come and see how some of the best artists
in Australia do what they do.

77.00.text:
Well, hi viewers and welcome back to
Color In Your Life.

79.70.text:
We're on the Sunshine Coast today
in a beautiful town called Nambour,

84.03.text: and I'm with a very talented man called Mr Brian Tisdall.

86.76.text: Thank you very much for being on the show, Bud.

88.23.text:
BRIAN : It's a pleasure Graeme.
Thanks for coming.

89.70.text:
GRAEME : Yeah, we've got...  Brian's
got a gallery right on the main street

92.43.text: as you saw as I just walked in,

93.67.text:
so you're probably going to hear a bit of
traffic noise today but that's okay.

96.17.text:
But that enables him obviously to work
in his studio right in the middle of the town

100.78.text:
it's great for people to come in
and have a chat to him.

102.94.text:
But in saying that you've had a really
interesting life as far as artist is concerned.

107.54.text:
Now you where born in Arusha,
in Tanzania...

110.13.text:
BRIAN : That's correct yeah.
GRAEME : ...in Africa.

111.60.text: And then you moved to Ireland.

113.20.text:
BRIAN : Yes.
GRAEME : And then came to Australia.

116.06.text:
GRAEME : Tell me a little bit more
about your travels then.

117.62.text: I was in Africa until I was 10.

119.11.text:
I went to boarding school there
for the first couple of years.

121.60.text:
GRAEME : Yeah.
BRIAN : And then we left there

125.78.text:
and things weren’t quite as
stable as they could be.

129.03.text:
So we went back home to the UK,
which mum's English dad's Irish,

132.85.text: we ended up living there for a while, but

134.67.text:
dad spent too much time in
Africa and enjoyed heat.

138.73.text:
GRAEME : How can you spend
too much time in Africa?

141.55.text:
GRAEME : Yeah that was a complete...
BRIAN : I spent a lot of time in Africa.

143.82.text:
So when we went back to Ireland, one winter
was enough and he said no, that's enough of that.

147.37.text:
And Australia’s a very
similar climate to Tanzania,

149.84.text:
so...
well this part of the world is.

153.28.text:
And I went to school in Nambour,
this wonderful little town here and we're in.

156.30.text:
GRAEME : Yeah you really have a love of art
since you were a child haven't you?

160.02.text:
BRIAN : Yeah.
GRAEME : It's really been something

161.21.text: that's been part of your life.

162.37.text:
I think by looking at Brian's work,
you can really see

164.89.text: there's a huge diversity in what you do,

167.39.text:
you're one of those artist's
that I think is probably restless...

170.15.text:
BRIAN : Yes.
GRAEME : ...in what you want to do.

171.73.text:
It's sort of like you see that
and want to create a vision.

176.28.text:
And your subject matters, it's all the way,
from cars to caricatures,

179.58.text:
which funnily enough today
we're actually going to be painting

183.61.text:
Which I think is a sensational
little character that you've developed.

187.68.text:
And tell us a little bit more about
your motivation towards your work.

191.30.text:
Basically I... since I was
little I just like drawing

193.85.text:
being brought up in Africa,
it's obviously a very inspiring country.

197.21.text:
There's animals, there's fantastic scenery,
there's everything,

200.51.text: and I'd just like to express that on paper.

203.15.text:
I have this urge, some people like
to take photos, I like to draw things.

206.83.text: You actually paint on surf boards as well,

208.71.text:
you've got T-shirt ranges
that you put out also,

211.38.text:
there's a myriad of different things
that you approach your work with.

213.77.text: And you're not afraid to do that.

215.41.text:
Where some artists are very conservative and
just go like, 'I just want to paint on canvas',

218.57.text: you see everything and want to paint on it.

220.41.text:
BRIAN : Yeah well if it stands still
long enough, it's fair game, you can paint it.

229.03.text:
develop one of your characters,
which I think is just really sensational.

233.25.text: You've got a wombat that you do a lot of...

236.00.text:
I think, sort of iconic
historical branding with it.

240.60.text:
He's got one and we'll just screen it up now,
of a wombat dressed as Napoleon.

247.42.text: He just arrived like most things do.

249.01.text: I don't know where they come from.

252.29.text:
and I think kangaroos and emus,
and everything else have been done a lot.

255.27.text: Wombats don't get much of a look in,

256.99.text:
and I like the sort of the weird,
wonderful world of a wombat.

260.99.text: So I started to draw the wombat thing.

265.04.text:
BRIAN : He needed a hat,
because he was a bit flat on top,

267.09.text:
so I gave him a hat and Napoleon's hat,
sort of a nice pointy thing.

270.44.text: GRAEME : They do have a flat head don't they.

272.56.text: So the hat came along well,

273.89.text:
and he obviously had to be
Napoleon wombat then, so...

276.30.text: GRAEME : Well I sort of looked at this

277.48.text:
and I thought of Norman Lyndsey
and Mel Fox straight away.

280.95.text:
Which are two really well known writers
and obviously Australian artists as well.

284.45.text:
I think there's a great synergy involved
with what your doing as well, so...

287.85.text:
BRIAN : It's good to just let
something happen and see where it goes.

290.96.text:
BRIAN : I don't know where
it comes from or where it's going too,

292.85.text: but I just sort of do it.

293.98.text:
GRAEME : That's great.
BRIAN : That's good.

295.63.text:
Let's go along and we'll create this
masterpiece with Brian and have a lot of fun.

299.95.text:
This is going to be a fun show,
because your going to see this,

302.75.text:
I think really whimsical character develop
and I think it's just great what you've done,

307.16.text:
but lets get to the canvas
and we'll make a start.

343.80.text:
GRAEME : Okay, well lets begin
this masterpiece of yours, but before we do,

347.39.text:
the company that you get
your canvas's off up here...

350.74.text:
GRAEME : Create Art. I mean Create Art
actually is, really sponsored us as well.

354.84.text: Helped us out a great deal in giving

356.70.text: canvases to people that needed them,

359.71.text: but they really, really support the arts industry

362.70.text: and this is one of their canvases.

364.61.text:
GRAEME : You've made a start on this.
BRIAN : I have.

368.35.text: You've got a sketch over there.

369.94.text: I think this is a really important part as well,

372.58.text:
is that you've started a sketch.
I think this character is just so great.

377.39.text:
But you can see that he's literally on...
it's like a little ship.

381.18.text:
Oh, no it's not.
It's a banjo isn't it?

382.99.text:
BRIAN : It's based on a one string guitar
where you put a broomstick on a box.

386.89.text:
BRIAN : The box became a hollow log
and the broomstick became a better stick.

391.14.text:
GRAEME : That's sensational isn't it.
BRIAN : Yeah so he's playing

392.96.text: a one string guitar was the idea.

394.62.text: I think it's beautiful, I really do.

395.96.text:
So I mean these are ideas themselves
they just simply come out of your head?

399.44.text:
GRAEME : Okay. Its just great.
it shows you what an imagination can do.

404.29.text: What are you going to do now?

406.25.text:
I mean obviously maybe put some
base colors down or...

410.10.text:
You can panic or you can just,
sort of go ahead.

412.79.text:
I usually just start putting some base colors
down,

416.23.text: and I've got a rough idea of what I want to do.

419.79.text: which is why I use the blue background,

421.59.text:
because that already makes you
feel like moonlight type thing.

425.45.text:
BRIAN : And yeah so, I'll just
put some basic background colors in

428.90.text: and see where it takes me.

430.32.text: GRAEME : Well lets pop some colors in then.

432.77.text:
Well this is my little palette
I like to work with when I do acrylics.

436.19.text: I've got oils which is similar.

437.53.text:
But with acrylic because I like
lots of color I make my own colors.

441.07.text:
This palette which is a watercolor palette
basically is really good.

443.90.text:
It's got little partitions so I've got
my rainbow of colors here ready to go.

447.67.text:
GRAEME : If they've gone off a little bit,
obviously the great part about that, is that...

450.31.text:
it's prevents them from going off
with the lid that you've got.

453.43.text: But you can just basically sprite them can you.

457.89.text:
BRIAN : Leave the lid on
and that keeps them from drying out too much.

462.98.text:
BRIAN : Or even a finer one
which a little atomic blaster here.

466.21.text:
BRIAN : And just, you can do that
as often as you like,

469.51.text:
just keep a wet skin on them
so the paint doesn’t dry off.

473.23.text:
GRAEME : So from here
we're going to start mixing some colors

475.48.text:
and putting them on to your canvas.
Where do we go?

479.61.text: I pick a brush which I'm not too fussy with.

482.08.text: I like these flat ones but,

485.65.text: just wet it first is always good

489.95.text:
I think I'll start with the sky in this one, so...
GRAEME : Okay.

492.14.text: BRIAN : We need a bit of blue.

493.22.text:
GRAEME : And you're obviously using
those Atelier colors they stand out,

496.34.text:
I mean the pigment in them
is pretty amazing isn't it?

499.15.text: They're good I like them they've done me well

501.36.text:
and when I've got a product
I'm sort of happy with, I stick with it.

504.50.text: Basically what I'm doing is just going to follow

507.27.text: all these little lines here that I've got,

509.16.text:
and work in the background area.
This bit will be the sky.

513.06.text:
So we follow through with that
around the edge of the clouds.

515.76.text:
I know, I've got the blue behind it but these...
GRAEME : Yeah.

520.27.text: just going to be my basics

521.82.text:
to help me think of what I'm doing
with the picture,

524.55.text:
and see what reaction I get
to the colors that are there.

527.73.text:
I get a little bit darker over here
just to add a bit more variety.

533.82.text: GRAEME :  I notice your, obviously working you do,

536.80.text: your demonstrations at the Eumundi Market,

538.80.text:
and other areas were people
are fascinated with what you do.

543.53.text: But I can see that a lot of your work is

546.30.text: very-- sort of hands on as well.

548.94.text:
You're not afraid to put the paint down,
where some other people are tentative,

552.73.text: you just dive straight in there.

554.17.text:
BRIAN : Yeah. Well the beauty
of acrylic is if you make a mistake,

557.12.text:
which really isn’t a mistake,
it's just something you don't like,

559.47.text: you can paint over the top.

562.99.text:
if you put something down and you think,
'Well, I don't like that',

565.40.text: let it dry, paint over the top of it.

567.38.text: Or just go straight into it and change the color.

569.48.text:
BRIAN : If that's not dark enough...
GRAEME : Yep.

572.30.text:
BRIAN : I'll just grab some more blue,
which is Cobalt Blue here,

574.79.text: and there you go instantly you've got it darker.

576.84.text: GRAEME : It's pretty forgiving isn't it?

578.02.text:
BRIAN : Yeah, and if you have color
and lumps in it,

580.84.text: as my friend Stan always calls it.

582.86.text:
GRAEME : Color and lumps.
BRIAN : Color and lumps.

584.68.text: It makes the painting more interesting

588.99.text: BRIAN : So we just keep going,

590.20.text:
keep going in that respect.
This is the edge of the clouds here.

594.56.text:
So I'll just give it a little
white lining on the edge.

598.60.text:
I mean the one thing
I really notice about your work is

602.73.text:
I mean the pure pigment in your paintings
just dive out at you.

608.28.text:
BRIAN : They are.
I like happy.

610.70.text: There's enough sad in the world.

611.92.text:
I mean, I have some little cartoon characters
like the koala with the trees all missing,

616.64.text:
that's pretty sad, but in the same respect,
it's cute little characters.

620.35.text:
But most of my work  I just like color,
it makes you feel good.

622.87.text:
And that's what I paint for
I like things that make me feel good. I just,

626.79.text: and get an urge to paint them.

632.95.text: GRAEME : Even looking around your gallery

634.47.text: I mean you've got such an extensive collection.

636.57.text: And the fact that you're so prolific as well.

639.16.text:
You've got, you can see that Brian,
really does have a love for his craft.

643.45.text: You love art and art seems to love you too.

647.14.text:
BRIAN : Yeah It's...
I mean if you're going to do a lot of it

649.34.text:
you need to enjoy it, so...
GRAEME : Absolutely.

651.49.text:
So with this I'll keep going
and fill all those areas in.

655.55.text: And I might do this tree a little bit darker,

659.91.text: add a different color and see what happens.

661.63.text: So I'll try a bit of purple in there.

663.23.text:
I'm never too worried about
putting to much color in.

665.73.text: You can't have to much color in your life can you?

669.36.text: And that's another thing that you do, do as well.

673.05.text: I mean, with the style of what you do

674.99.text: which is so electric and fun.

677.71.text:
There's people that obviously
ask you to do murals in various areas.

681.74.text: BRIAN : Yeah I have done a lot.

682.84.text:
I slowed down a bit because
I had some health issues

685.08.text: and had both my shoulders reconstructed,

687.04.text:
so I couldn’t actually do the physical work
of murals for a few years.

690.94.text:
But I got that all sorted and did a mural
just last week or the week before.

696.84.text:
GRAEME : Okay
BRIAN : On a pool fence for a guy.

700.59.text:
Which is really, yeah, good fun doing
a Color Bond pool fence painting

704.19.text: a sea scape which is all horizontal,

706.67.text: and you can only make brush strokes this long.

711.05.text:
BRIAN : You got to work your
painting down like this,

712.95.text: go around a little thing, blend it down.

717.88.text:
Yes, so it stiffens it up a bit.
It makes it a challenge.

721.17.text:
And another thing that
you're quite well known for,

724.11.text:
and you do a lot of this as well,
and that's a really burgeoning art style,

729.70.text: and it's great participation for kids

733.18.text: and people watching it and that's chalk art.

735.54.text:
BRIAN : Yeah.
GRAEME : And its really become

737.26.text: quite a distinct field on its own.

739.23.text:
Yeah that's good fun something a will ago
while I was at the Eumundi Markets

742.82.text: we had the body art festival

745.11.text: and they wanted to do a chalk art demonstration.

747.41.text:
And the manager at the time said,
'can you do chalk art',

750.42.text:
and I always liked the idea.
GRAEME : Yeah.

752.87.text:
And I thought well it's just drawing
with chalk which is like pastels,

755.28.text:
it's just on the ground.
So I said, 'yeah',

758.09.text:
and I started doing chalk art,
and yeah it's good fun.

761.34.text:
They have like world championships,
and people travel to Europe or America.

765.34.text:
BRIAN : Oh they do,
and there's some huge ones, yeah.

768.49.text:
Jenny McCracken went over to Spain as the
Australian entrant and I think she won.

773.14.text:
GRAEME : Yeah well Jenny's
one of the best, known in the world...

777.61.text:
BRIAN : She's a brilliant artist
and her work is just phenomenal.

780.45.text:
GRAEME : And a lot of it has to do
with the 3 dimensional effect.

782.89.text: BRIAN : Yeah, that's what I like about it.

785.31.text:
Painting a hole in the ground
that's not actually there.

789.18.text:
Sometimes when I'm not sure
which bit to get to...

791.64.text:
GRAEME : Yeah.
BRIAN : I'll just pick something

793.58.text:
that's bright and strong.
I thought with this wombat

797.06.text: for some reason I think he needs a waist coat,

799.21.text:
or he's a muso or
maybe he's playing in a jazz band.

803.14.text:
So I thought I'd just for a bit of variety add
some color because it's going to be

806.47.text:
mainly moonlight and blue,
I'll just add some red.

812.64.text: Okay you've sort of really mapping those colors in

815.29.text:
and we still want that moon
to be a little brighter.

817.16.text:
BRIAN : As you go little things
pop into your head

819.38.text:
and you sort of say,
'I need to do this',

821.33.text: or put a color here, or there, or something.

827.29.text: That's got that out of my head.

828.63.text:
And the other thing is this is
actually on the Sunshine Coast,

834.22.text:
this wombat and he's flying through
the glass house mountains.

836.13.text:
GRAEME : Is he okay?
BRIAN : Yeah.

838.94.text:
I think he's riding on the air,
or a g string or something...

842.91.text:
GRAEME : Well I mean, that's what I thought
when I first saw the drawing,

845.41.text: is that it looked like he was leaning forward

847.27.text:
and floating through the forest
on this one stringed guitar.

854.51.text:
BRIAN : He is, I've been trying to tie,
somewhere in the back of my mind I suppose,

860.04.text:
whose the wombat, with something local,
so it's the Sunshine Coast.

863.87.text:
BRIAN : I did one before
where he's sitting on a...

866.42.text:
sort of down the beach in Moolooaba
with Point Cartwright in the background.

869.98.text: It just relates him to the local area.

872.22.text:
GRAEME : Sure.
BRIAN : And this guy...

873.69.text: instead of just flying through a forest,

875.02.text:
I'm going to put the Glass House Mountains
in which I'll put in here now.

879.06.text:
BRIAN : So they're obviously going to be
a little bit darker in silhouette.

882.82.text: So that's the beauty of art.

885.35.text: There are no rules, there's no right or wrong.

887.28.text:
There's no mistakes.
You just do stuff.

889.29.text:
BRIAN : And if you don't like it,
and you've done something you don't like,

891.06.text:
you change it and make it into
something you do like.

893.04.text:
I read the other day that your brain knows
what it's doing, so get out of its way.

899.96.text:
Yes so this is still basically
blocking in at this stage.

904.37.text:
GRAEME : So I mean obviously
having your own gallery gives you

907.82.text:
the opportunity to have your own shows
in your own gallery as well.

912.39.text:
A lot of artists tend to book
into other peoples galleries,

917.36.text:
but because you've made the move
to create your own,

920.55.text:
you've really got a perpetual show
going all the time.

924.77.text:
Yeah, so come in anytime and
see the works of Brian and

928.47.text: my friend Stan and Don and Bob and Ian.

931.96.text:
GRAEME : You do paint
in watercolors as well don't you?

933.86.text:
BRIAN : Yeah I do,
I've done a lot of watercolors.

935.28.text: GRAEME : From what I can gather in your CV

937.76.text:
and all the work that I can see is that you've
got a broad attitude towards your work.

941.85.text:
Looks like you've mastered
all the mediums as well.

944.63.text:
BRIAN : Oh that's very kind of you.
Obviously the more you do with a particular medium

947.80.text: or particular thing the better you get at it,

951.51.text:
To me paint is paint,
and brushes are brushes,

953.52.text:
and you just find a surface and
bung them all on there and see what happens.

957.08.text:
Okay I might let Brian block in
a little bit more of the base colors

961.10.text:
and then we'll come back when
he's got a bit more done.

963.17.text: And then start to put some finer detail in

965.28.text:
and get those light sources going
and go from there.

1015.98.text:
GRAEME : Well as you can see Brian
is really  starting to map this together.

1019.24.text: I love the vibrancy of Brian's colors.

1021.54.text:
But why this particular color scheme
for this picture?

1024.82.text:
BRIAN : Ah, well I sort of trying
to restrain myself a little bit

1029.62.text:
and in the moonlight
you don't get really bright colors.

1031.30.text:
GRAEME : Yeah.
BRIAN : But what I want to do is

1032.81.text: keep it shades of blues and purples

1035.43.text:
and then have some little
goldy highlights coming out through,

1039.14.text:
So, when you get the moonlight glinting,
obviously you can exaggerate a bit,

1043.22.text:
but if I go too far
it's going to look more like daylight.

1046.44.text:
The red jacket is obviously
too strong at the moment,

1050.13.text:
that's a base color under it.
So I'll have to soften that one back,

1053.43.text:
and the-- and yeah the red's just,
when you've got a lot of blues and greens,

1058.27.text:
and you throw a bit of red into it,
it makes the whole thing sing,

1060.74.text:
so I often use the opposite color...
GRAEME : Yep.

1064.32.text:
or a bit of red or a bit of orange
against a lot of blue

1066.99.text:
and that really comes right up.
GRAEME : Just picks it up.

1069.86.text:
Same as if you were doing
a painting that's all reds and oranges,

1072.19.text: and if you put a bit of bright blue on it,

1076.94.text: So, I just like the rainbow effect.

1078.64.text:
If there's a color missing
I better stick it in there somewhere.

1081.25.text:
GRAEME : Sure, using the complementaries
to juxtapose each other.

1084.17.text:
BRIAN : Yeah sort of, it just sort of comes.
I don't think about it too much.

1087.93.text:
I'll probably analyse it more there,
than I would in my head.

1090.82.text:
And normally I just start
and the color feels right.

1094.25.text: So you've got to go with what you feel.

1096.54.text: And what I do when I get to this stage

1099.61.text:
is putting things down. I start looking
at the things if I'm comfortable with something,

1104.36.text: and that's what I look at fixing.

1106.38.text:
If I'm not sure where to go next
to make something specifically work,

1111.10.text:
there's no point in putting something down
if you don't know what you're putting down.

1113.43.text:
You get to a point were you look at it
and something annoys you,

1116.33.text:
so work backwards and fix the thing that annoys
you by changing its color, tone, rearranging it.

1122.28.text: That way you get to a point in the picture

1126.49.text:
you're also, by the same token
going somewhere good.

1130.12.text:
GRAEME : But I think just the
fun aspect of your work

1132.76.text:
and using your imagination
a lot of people just simply you know,

1138.45.text:
take a picture and paint it. But your...
this is all coming out of your head.

1142.06.text: Yeah, like with the orange, something just in me,

1144.42.text:
sort of made this brush go and pick up
some orange and stick it there.

1148.03.text:
GRAEME : Okay.
BRIAN : So I've done it.

1150.86.text:
Do you have a direction that you want
to take your work into as you go along?

1154.99.text: Is there something you specifically want to--

1158.24.text:
To master or create, in the process of--
Brian Tisdall doing what he wants to do?

1163.49.text: I would like to do a whole series of this going,

1165.96.text:
and maybe get a story line
and put it into a book or...

1172.03.text: I think has got potential to go somewhere.

1173.83.text:
And I like the little characters...
GRAEME : Yeah.

1175.93.text:
I mean you could end up with
a whole lot of them.

1177.50.text:
With the little wombat and the koala characters
and all the other Australian characters,

1181.35.text: and just put them all into a book.

1183.10.text:
GRAEME : Yeah I think it's a great idea.
BRIAN : And that way

1184.67.text:
you could have the final painting,
a picture for each illustration, each character.

1189.03.text:
Alright, where you are now mate,
I can just see that

1192.31.text:
you really  starting to refine that
background layer that you put down there.

1197.24.text:
You're really sort of starting to smooth
a lot of that roughness out of there

1200.29.text: to get those really lovely tone effects.

1205.00.text:
Yeah as I was saying the brush strokes
were sort of annoying me

1208.13.text:
with this particular painting
because I wanted it to be a bit smoother.

1211.18.text:
And this is where,
I mean the whole process slows down a lot now.

1214.88.text:
BRIAN : To get the details
you want to refine it a little bit,

1216.95.text: and be a bit more careful with your brush strokes.

1219.02.text:
And when you're putting your original background
down all this sort of stuff

1222.34.text: it's lot looser, a lot freer,

1225.28.text:
and then when you want to start
refining and bringing out highlights

1227.76.text: and shadows you need to put them more carefully.

1233.70.text: I might just go around the edge of this.

1235.42.text: GRAEME : A really moonlight, look at that

1237.03.text: BRIAN : And get it a little...

1238.42.text: GRAEME : It really pops it out, doesn't it?

1239.48.text:
BRIAN : ...shiny edge.
GRAEME : What one line can do sometimes.

1241.68.text: BRIAN : Yeah, it's the same with this.

1242.97.text: So you follow that as far as you want to.

1244.54.text:
I mean, obviously if you suddenly find
you've done to much,

1247.45.text:
well you can get some more of that sort of color
and kill it back again.

1250.27.text:
GRAEME : Sure. Well that's just fantastic fun.
BRIAN : Ta.

1252.87.text:
GRAEME : We're going to let Brian
continue on to finish this off

1256.60.text: and we're going to head on out of here.

1259.08.text:
But you'll obviously see the finished
picture screened up as we go along,

1264.71.text: but its been just great being here today.

1267.62.text:
And I think your ideas and
your approach to your work is just fantastic.

1273.50.text: GRAEME : It's got so many possibilities.

1276.31.text:
When you look at this character and I think that
you're wanting to develop this even further.

1280.46.text:
BRIAN : Yeah he's a fun character
and I like painting him.

1282.87.text:
He's got potential, might turn into all sorts
of different things and have a bit of a life.

1284.85.text:
he might turn into all sorts of different things,
GRAEME : Yeah,I think it's great

1287.41.text:
BRIAN : and have a bit of a life.
GRAEME : I really do

1288.83.text: just the work you produce is so much fun.

1293.65.text:
GRAEME : But thank you so much
for having us in your studio today.

1295.42.text: BRIAN : Thank you, thanks for coming in.

1296.41.text:
GRAEME : I think it was great.
Now if people want to see some more of your work,

1306.20.text:
GRAEME : And do you have
a Facebook page as well?

1307.59.text:
BRIAN : I do have a Facebook page
and it's Brian's Tisdall Gallery.

1314.27.text:
GRAEME : But just a really fun day
with an amazing man.

1317.22.text:
And I think this character
he's developed is just incredible.

1319.92.text:
GRAEME : If you want to see
some of Brian's work as well

1322.00.text: we're going to have that up in our shop.

1323.55.text: I mean I insist on having you in there.

1325.22.text:
BRIAN : Sure, that'd be good.
GRAEME : We sell tons...

1326.78.text:
We sell tons of paintings
through our shop these days

1329.38.text: so if you are artists out there,

1330.97.text:
please come in and put some
of your work into the store that we have.

1335.48.text:
We really are selling paintings
right across the globe these days,

1338.94.text: so it's just silly not to be there.

1340.66.text:
But you can come into
colourinyourlife.com.au

1344.73.text:
and see what we've got going on,
lots of exciting stuff.

1347.25.text:
We've got amazing artists
coming on board these days.

1350.03.text:
I just think it's fabulous
what's going on with us.

1352.90.text: But until we meet again, as we always say,

1358.08.text:
some color in your life...
BRIAN : Color in your life.

1359.17.text: GRAEME : ...and we'll see you next time.
